Life in Lockdown: Awards as a positive end to the year

27/05/2020

Nouse talks to YUSU president Samara Jones and presenters Alex and Naomi about the upcoming YUSU Awards Season

Image by YUSU

By Jonathan Wellington

'Life in Lockdown' is an interview series focusing on people, organisations or student societies who are adapting to isolation in interesting and innovative ways. If youâ€™d like to talk about your experiences in lockdown or share how your student group has adjusted during the pandemic, email editor@nouse.co.uk; weâ€™d love to hear from you.

This week Nouse took a focus on the upcoming YUSU awards season speaking to YUSU President Samara Jones and presenting duo Alex West and Naomi Gildert.

Starting the conversation with Samara, reflecting on how being a sabb has changed through lockdown the YUSU president tells us that â€œthereâ€™s some nice things in a way, because there's no commute into work and although I do actually miss having to get up at this point, if Iâ€™ve got a 9am meeting I can pretty much roll out of bed, throw on some clothes and Iâ€™m already there. You donâ€™t have to factor in getting to work so itâ€™s kind of simpler in a way. Getting between meetings is also simpler especially if Iâ€™ve got one right after another it means you can get there by clicking three buttons instead of turning up out of breath.â€

In terms of her day to day activity, Samara tells us that sheâ€™s â€œspending an awful amount of time on Zoomâ€ adding that â€œyesterday I barely left my computer which is quite draining but I think actually people are a lot more efficient in meetings on Zoom. People mute themselves if theyâ€™re not talking, they tend to be running a bit more orderly with far fewer tangents.â€ The usual aspects of day-to-day life are what many are missing right now. The hurried crumpet on the way to the library, the RKC Costa around lunchtime, the list goes on. When asked what sheâ€™s missing, Samara says â€œit's just that normal social interaction in the office (Did everyone get that spam email for fancy headphones?) Itâ€™s that interaction with the rest of the team, you canâ€™t just go and find someone - itâ€™s the lack of that casual social interaction which Iâ€™m finding, not harder, but you miss doing it in that simple way.â€ Despite this, Samara adds that sheâ€™s â€œalmost seeing sabbs more than before because we have three time weekly meetings where weâ€™re all in the meeting at the same time which is rare because we used to play sabb bingo: how many sabbs we can get in the office and itâ€™s very rarely all of us.â€

The last couple of weeks have also seen Samara and the YUSU team complete a big manifesto aim in the establishment of the Covid-19 Forum. The forum has seen some success in its first week with Samara telling us she was â€œshocked that within the first 24 hours of it going live weâ€™d had 15 submissions and only five of those were pre-prepared, just because no one wants to be the first to submit something. Thereâ€™s been some really interesting questions and itâ€™s reinforced some stuff which we thought was a big issue but now weâ€™ve got a bit more backing from students to take to the University. With the dissertation printing that was a simple question but students can still get theirs printed and thatâ€™s now clearer as an effect of the forum.â€

Conversation then moved onto the upcoming YUSU Awards Season, which will go ahead to the usual schedule, but entirely online. The Colours Ball, which is run by York Sport Union, will take place on Sunday 7th June and a full rundown of its shortlist can be found HERE.

â€œTheyâ€™ll all be livestreamed on our Facebook page starting at 7pm. Itâ€™s been the normal process for nominations, shortlisting and judging, except weâ€™re not all sat around a table. â€œKeep an eye out on the YUSU Facebook where thereâ€™ll be some events that you can click going on. Hopefully theyâ€™ll be bigger and better than ever before.â€

Samara sympathises with this inevitably awkward process saying that when she was recording her speeches, â€œthe number of takes I did because I didnâ€™t say that word quite right or went slightly off what I wanted to say was huge. â€œThere were pages and pages of nominations which was great to see especially with everything weâ€™re going through at the moment.
